title: 112_hr4317
content: The Act is titled the "Iranian Energy Sector and Proliferation Sanctions Act" and it expands sanctions on Iran's energy sector. The "Iranian Energy Sector and Proliferation Sanctions Act" states that the revenues from Iran's energy sector may fund nuclear activities and prohibits international business with Iran's energy sector. Sanctions will be imposed on entities in the energy sector of Iran. The Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.) imposes sanctions on entities involved in Iran's energy sector, regardless of where the activities take place. Sanctions under the Powers Act target entities involved in Iran's energy sector, including those providing goods, services, or technology related to development, production, extraction, or transportation. Services encompass various areas such as transportation, insurance, software, hardware, and professional consulting. Sanctions do not apply to those purchasing crude oil from Iran. Sanctions under the Powers Act target entities involved in Iran's energy sector, including those providing goods, services, or technology related to development, production, extraction, or transportation. Sanctions do not apply to those purchasing crude oil from Iran. The President may waive sanctions for national security reasons for up to 120 days, renewable for additional periods, with a report to Congress. The President can waive sanctions under the Powers Act for national security reasons, with a report to Congress detailing cooperation received. The Comptroller General must submit reports every 180 days identifying entities described in the Act, in unclassified form with a possible classified annex. No requirement for sanctions imposition. The section defines terms related to sanctions on persons involved in joint ventures for petroleum development outside of Iran. Key terms include "appropriate congressional committees," "petrochemical product," and "refined petroleum products."
